author: RumHam1
body:
Right now, I really like AMAT for a 5 year+ hold.  They're a semi equipment stock with a forward p/e around 17.  

They have dropped from 160 to about 143 after a narrow miss in earnings and predictions of supply chain disruptions for the next few quarters, coupled with this sell off yesterday . 

 I've got a position with a 135 cost basis, and if we see much weakness next week I'm probably loading the boat in the 125-130 range.

author: Professional_Curve90
body:
FYI, “pure quality” silicon is usually obtained through Czochralski method that lead to a massive silicon beam that is then sliced into wafers (see [here](https://www.tf.uni-kiel.de/matwis/amat/semitech_en/kap_4/backbone/r4_1_3.html) ). Foundry now use 300mm as a standards to process, where as dated before the etch, etc the Si. Implantation is also needed with very pure other elements, usually in gas form such as Boron, and phosphorus or arsenide to create the doped area that are so needed for transistor. Therefor not only silicon is needed I. Silicon foundry. 
In addition III-V material (from the third and 5th column of metals in the periodic table) are becoming more and more used, especially for active photonics element (think laser, used a lot for transducer in data center for instance, with intel design) and most of the ressource of III-V are in China.

author: Ozymandias_12
body:
There are better stocks in the semi conductor sector like AMAT, ASML, LRCX, KLIC, KLAC, UMC etc. that I would buy before I'd consider Intel. TSM and Samsung are both spending 100 billion each on fabs, and somehow Intel's 20 billion plus whatever subsidy they get from the US is suddenly gonna change everything?

The entire economic system can collapse and Intel will stay at the 40-60 range. Hell, even if the Sun expanded and half of Earth is disintegrated, Intel will stay in that range.

author: seigy
body: My take is $TSM makes high-end chips for NVDA & AMD, $GFS makes a mix of chips, $UMC makes legacy chips (main thing we are currently short on), $INTC makes their own chips.  There are others but I think these are the big fabs and foundries.  I believe $QCOM, $AVGO, $SKWS, $TXN make their own and get some from fans but I am not certain on them.  Other plays to consider are the equipment mfg who make the equipment, parts, and services the fabs are buying in order to make more chips.  Some big players here are $AMAT, $ASML, & $LRCX.

author: vizk0sity
body:
tool suppliers. I personally hold AMAT, LAM RESEARCH, KLAC, TSM. You can add in more such as ASML, Tokyo Electron Limited. ASML has a monopoly on the EUV but they are limited by the supplier's capacity (you can't make as many as you'd like). This is the same as the TSM problem. One thing to remember, semiconductor is a cyclical business and won't go up forever. When oversupply/stockage happens, it will last for a few quarters. Most of these stocks will pull back. I don't expect them to have any oversupply until possibly at the earliest, late 2022 however. Watch the capex as usually that indicates expansion in the industry.

Fyi, I work for process dev. engineer in a fab for 6 years. If my opinion matters to you.

author: seigy
body:
Yep, for some reason people seem to be blind as to just how big the market is and how much money is being invested.  I posted this as part of an assessment of money flows in a different subreddit last weekend.  I have even read a few more semi investment plans since.   

Semiconductor fabs and foundries spending plans: 
Samsung $205B/3yrs, 
Micron $150B/10yrs, 
Intel $115B/3yrs, 
Taiwan Semi $100B/3yrs, 
United Micro $2B in 2022, 
SK Hynix $235B/10yrs. 
Major plays $LRCX, $ASML, $AMAT, $TER. 
Minor plays $NUE, $X, $CLF, $VMC, $FCX, $URI, $CAT.

My favorite quote I read this week that shows just this was from Pat Gelsinger: “I think I have more concrete trucks working for me today than any other human on the planet,” Gelsinger said. “We have construction in Oregon, New Mexico, Arizona, Ireland and Israel. And we expect to plant our next major fabs in the U.S. and Europe before the end of this year.”

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
These are both risky because they have a lot of expectations built in. For example, the price rise that NVDA got out of the ARM acquisition announcement presumes that they intend to behave in a monopolistic way, and can squeeze that market without vendors switching to RISC-V. And that the won't receive any significant regulatory response. Otherwise, the acquisition price makes no financial sense at all, it is just tossing money out the window. 

INTC has similar problems. People are bullish because they're building a fab. When they tried to contract out use of their existing fabs in the past, they did very poorly at it; they were greedy, they were unwilling to offer competitive prices. And when people wouldn't pay a premium just to have the honor of being their customer, they discontinued the service instead of lowering prices. And they made a lot of excuses about what had happened.

Basically none of that is going to find its way into either technical or fundamental analysis. That is why I don't touch either of these stocks, and I prefer companies like AMD, AMAT, and even IBM. (What I like about IBM is that the bear case has been very popular, everybody can say something bad about them, and yet they're doing a great job of integrating their AI tools with the cloud and providing quality APIs to developers; and they're doing that while maintaining high margins and large revenue)

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
>TXN

I love TXN as a company. I do firmware and I use gcc compiler instead of proprietary ones (so I have a consistent toolchain across device vendors) and when I hit a bug in the example code for a T I chip, I posted to their forums and an engineer answered with a fix within 4 hours. And I posted from my personal login and email without disclosing any company information. They're really great. And their example code is all high quality. Very wonderful company.

But everybody else thinks so too, their stock price is really high... they'll get murdered in a downturn.

I remember when AMD spun theirs fabs off to GFS and people said it was the death of AMD! 🤣 But it is hard to know what GFS is worth this early in the filings game.

AMAT is great too, but if not all the anticipated fabs get built they'll get hammered.

ON is way up in a couple weeks. I'm hoping they'll come back down. If they do, I'll look for an entry point; though, they're probably undervalued even after the bump, with a P/S under 4. They're sortof a sleeper with the US fabs that will come online, because there will be more board assembly done in the US, and in the US people care about getting the specified part. In China they like substitutions, so almost everything gets generic mosfets and amplifiers. When American Engineers want a good mosfet, ON is one of the shortlist choices. And their prices are good. I normally swing trade, but if I get a good entry on ON I'll probably hold that.

author: JhoLow_1MDB
body: My take is just own the damn shares. Semis are the new oil and lifeblood of any advanced economy. We are entering a 4th industrial revolution that is entirely driven by semiconductors. AI, Quantum computing, IOT, cloud everything....it all requires chips....which require fabrication.  AMAT also has expertise in equipment to make advanced displays and screens.  It'll only become more and more important as the metaverse is built out.  AMAT is one of the most important companies in the entire country and is a great way to cash in on basically all big tech movements. Own the damn shares for life. It is a fantastic company unlike all of the other speculative crap that makes up 99% of the stuff here.

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
I posted about the McDonalds deal last week, a few people are talking about them.😉

>most big companies spinoff apart of their business because well it’s to unload all the garbage debt that the parent company (IBM owns). So all bad debt now going to that spinoff company

The real problem is that IBM has a longstanding, very successful managed IT services division. 30 years ago that was high margin, but now it is low margin. And now they're more focused on cloud services. These units are directly competing. And it creates confusion for existing customers. By spinning off the old-school part of the IT consulting services, they clarify things a lot. It can be awkward to negotiate contracts when you're competing with yourself. And the industry has moved strongly to "hybrid cloud," with multi-vendor support, so they can get more money from the managed infrastructure clients in the spinoff, where those clients might choose some other cloud provider. And IBM can stay focused on being a cloud and AI provider.

Kyndryl isn't full of debt it is just low-margin and contains a lot of harmful redundancy that may thrive separately.

IBM has been doing major partnerships for almost 100 years, they're not the sort of company that creates a bunch of debt they can't pay and have to stuff in a suitcase. Check their credit rating.

The Palo Alto deal sounds really good, that could be a big winner for both. The Cisco deal will likely be irrelevant unless Cisco finds a better angle for a 5G play. The Boston Dynamics thing may be pretty good, but it is always hard to tell with BD if it is just going to result in nice videos. The Raytheon thing is good for Raytheon in the short term, and in the very-unlikely event that quantum computing actually impacts computer security in the next 100 years, it will help them both to have a working relationship in place.

IBM has a lot of other stuff going on too. They recently signed a deal to take over Honda's European finance and procurement operations. They've been "global allies" with Deloitte for over 20 years are going to offer a new AI-backed anti-fraud service to governments, for example to identify tax fraud.

Most of what they do flies under the radar, but they've got a lot going on, and the extra free cash flow they'll get from spinning off the legacy IT will really help them.

author: Due-Cryptographer
body: The stock is in a massive bubble, larger than Cisco in 1999. When this happens, it is what you call a ticking time bomb and floats around until it inevitably finds a pin to pop it.

author: RoPrime12
body:
Look at all the dotcom stocks. Microsoft and Amazon are the few that reached new highs (after 15years for microsoft). Many of the highfliers went bankrupt or still didn't reach it's high after 20+ years (Cisco, Intel, Microstrategy, Yahoo). 

Price matters and the company has a P/S of 120. Plug their numbers into a DCF (using their non-Gaap earnings, and assume an annual EPS of $0,12). Using 100% growth the first five years and 50% from year 5-10, a PE of 30 and a target rate of return of 15%, we arrive at a maximum price of $216,24.  The company increased revenue 50% a year tho, so using 50% growth for the 10 years, we arrive at a price of $51,31. 

Looking at the FAANG stocks, not a single one could increase revenue 50%+ for a decade. 

So even if everything goes perfectly for Cloudflare and 50% growth for a decade, you loose heavily. If they grow 100% a year (which they don't even do now), you have an upside of less than 8%.

author: jessejerkoff
body:
You're looking at from too close. Step back a bit!

Iaas will go the way of legacy infrastructure. Case in point: networking in the 90s used to be next big thing to eat the world, everything will be connected (iot correctly predicted) and networking is always the problem, and Cisco is so ahead of everything else.... And even if not, Palo alto and juniper and Cisco will split the world between each other!

Do you see the parallels yet?

Cisco was prophesied (and I think at one brief moment also was) the biggest company in the world.

Margins will be run into the ground and even without the tech bubble those grandiose predictions would not have come true. And technology will be leapfrog this current paradigm.

author: yeppersbruh
body:
This is one of the most moronic comments I've seen in a while.

Cisco's market cap was like $500B back in 2000. Then the stock fell by 80%. 20 years later today, Cisco has a market cap of $250B. It never reached the valuation it had back then.

This can happen to any stock. But you know what? The moment you see monetary tightening people will stop dreaming and punish the shit out of this stocks valuation. Just like what we saw in the beginning of 2021 when everyone was missing and shitting themselves because of inflation and higher rates.

Teslas stock is going to collapse. I won't make/lose money by going long, I won't make/lose money by going short because the risk/reward is skewed and market participants have completely lost their minds. But I'm convinced that this thing will collapse at some point. And then, like always, everybody will not only hate the stock but also hate the stock market. Which is when I'm going to buy in big. :)

author: JRshoe1997
body: Yeah and they were one out of the many companies that didnt go bankrupt during the internet bubble. Only Apple, Microsoft, Qualcomm, and Amazon are higher then what they were at the peak. Cisco, and Intel still havent recovered and the rest went bankrupt. People investing in Tesla are justifying their valuations on what they think they are going to do and EVs are going to change the world. EVs are not going to change the world. You wanna know what really changed the world forever? The internet, it changed the way we live, how we communicate, and how we live our lives, and how we think. Yet many companies involved in it crashed and went bankrupt.

author: Admirable_Nothing
body: I would vote for luckiest.  Few had that kind of foresight.  Tech was the Cat's Meow in 99 and the Untouchable from 2002 onward.  Remember NASDAQ lost near 80% of its value and did not recover until late 2014/2015.  So Tech was dead for over 14 years.  Heck Cisco just regained its mid 2000 value this past year and it is a very strong and long term successful Tech company.  So that is 21 years under water.
